document.text: Young Postoffice Robbers. Newark Special.  Commissioner Jones had before him George Melius, 14 years old, of Minebrook, charged with recent robberies of the Minebrook postoffice. Two other boys, aged 9 and 10, were implicated, but on account of their youth, they were not arrested. Melius pleaded guilty and was remand ed. The boy had Seen janitor of the district school, and had learned that they key of the schoolhouse door fitted the door of the postoffice.

document.text: You are cordially invited to the regular preaching service, at Zion Baptist Church Sunday, May 4 at 11. a.m. The Male Chofus is having its second anniversary Sun day, May 4 at 3 p.m. at Zion Baptist. The. Senior- Usher Board met Sunday at 11 a.m. with vice president Barbara Hunter calling the meeting to order. Our chaplain, Mr. Waverly Gray was in charge of the devotion. Mrs. Nannie Johnson, recording secre tary, took minutes. The Usher Board is planning for their anniver sary the second Sunday .in June. You are cordially invited to our Mothers Dfcy program on the second Sunday in May at 11 a.m. Our guest speaker will be the. Rev. H. O. Flood, and the Male Chorus will perform. document.text: Yon can imagine whether we felt acquainted or not after that. His father and I had been boys together. Well, sir. meeting young Jones was the most pleasant part of my trip You cant tell what good fortune may befall you when you start on a jour- ney. Elections in Brazil. A writer in Argonaut declares that in Brazil the elections arc a farce, tne ballots are hardly ever counted, for the government nominates its ticket, ana then, after an election, announces all its candidates elected. A year or so ago. he says, an American, who had settled in Bahia, the second largest city in Brazil, was made an election clerK, ard was told to bring the returns from an interior towm into Bahia. After the electron had closed, the clerk took the returns nd hastened away, guarding them with the greatest car. He rode his horse hart, for he felt that the sus pense would be great at Bahia until the returns he was carrying were received. What was his chagrttl, therefore, to hand his package over to the chiet election clerk, only to, see it thrown into the waste-basket. .  Here, what are you doing? he shouted. . Throwing them away, was the an swer, we dont need-them now.  Dont need them? stammered the American, who had been brought up to regard a violation of the election laws as treasonable. .  The government has eiccted its men already, was the answer we don t need any more voles.  Here the inspector opened the pack age and showed the astonished Ameri can a quantity of blanks, each of which was signed, with a space to be fills! in with any number necessary to elect the government candidates.  ----------- - --------- -  man Amusements Halls tor our Soldiers. wj1QS A year ago Congress appropriated five hundred thousand 4ollars for the construction and equipment of amuse- ment halls at first-class army posts, and the p a building for this purpose to cost one H hundred and twenty-five thousand dol- A lars is to be constructed at Fort Myer. lars. The building is to be sixty-eiglit by one exact hundred tin a seventy-two feet, ts to be O I-shapcd. and will contain a large And swimming pool, a complete gymnasium, comf a running track, a bowling alley, a from shooting gallery, billiard room, library, lecture room, cafe, and a good-sized stage for theatricals and other literary exercises. The bnilding will be use! for the regular religious exercises on Sundays and will be managed, so as.to contribute as much as pv-..-.--- j - entertainment and improvement ot tne men stationed at the post, the cate will dispense what are known as sou drinks, and the usual foods kept at such a place. The aim is to provide a means of intellectual and moral improvement which will, as far as possible, take the place of the old time canteen and keep the men from desiring to resort to the groggeries that beset the roadways to every army post. The remainder of the appropriation will be divided rtt maxi mum amounts of forty thousand dol lars among other army jiosts designated by the Secretary of War.

document.text: Yes, yss, pursued he  nosewide at the roots, and sot up good sign. Haint you had the smallpox lately? No, said X, indignantly.  Oh, you haint? I seed the sides of yer face and yer upper Up was kinder broke out and dingy. Broke out, indeed! and my mus tache as respectable a size as any one could expect from three months nursing. And only yesterday Ara- minta Jones had said it was divine, and just as scratchy as need be. I was angry, but a glance at the sweet face of Bessie made me re strain my temper. What could I not bear for her sake? I used to know pretty near all your folks, said old Blake,  and theres a heap of em I should like to ask about if I could only get my wits to work. Thera was your Uncle Joshua you dont remember him, I guess he died afore your time   I never had an Uncle Joshua, said I. Dont contradict me, my boy, said he, testily  I ghess I know. Taint likely they ever told you any thing about him. He was put in the state prison for stealing sheep or was it a pig? Now, father, said the old lady, dont you go for to harrering up the boys feelings. He cant help what his uncle did.   I haint a harrering, said old Blake, crossly.  You mind your own bizness, Martha.  And while the old people were dis puting as to the real meaning of the word  harrerin, I improved the chance which offered, and kissed Bes sie. Before this fact was accomplished, a tall, red-whiskered man strode into the room, and, for an instant, stood glaring at me like a wild beast. Then he dashed toward me, seized me by the collar and planted his foot at that part of my body most convenient to kick, and landed ine at the other side of the room. Take that, you scoundrel! he re marked, impressively but I could not oblige him. I had already taken it. I rose to my feet and prepared to strike out. What do you mean, sir? de manded I, before striking. What do you mean, sir? de nwinded he. What do you mean by kissing my wife?  Your wife! Jupiter Jorum! cried I.  Bessie Blake your wife?  Bessie Blake? said he.  Whc in thunder is Bessie Blake?  Dont be profane, my son, said old Mrs. Blake.  Scripter is agin it.  Are you not Bessie Blake? said I, turning to the Venus. No, said she  my name is Annie Hall. Well, said I, this is a pretty kettle of fish. Who are you, sir? to the red-whiskered man.  I am Robert Hall, at your service  Mr. Blakes step-son.  Isnt this Mr. Moses Blakes house?  No my name is Jeremiah, said old Blake.  And I was going to Moses Blakes, said I.  Why in the deuce didnt ydu go there, then? cried Mr. Hall.  Dont swear, Robert, expostu lated Mrs. Blake.  How, was I to tell one house from another in this abominable village? cried I, indignantly,  where every hou.se is just like every other one.  My house cost twice as much as Moses Blakes, said Mr. lake. Aint your name Jeremiah? asked Mrs. Blake. Mercy forbid! said I.  Then, said she,  I guess things is kinder mixed up. We are expect ing our nephew, Jeremiah Muggins, for to pay us a visit. He writ some time ago to say hed come. We haint seen him sence he was a child, and naterly we took you for him. And the fact of it is youve got into the wrong house. I saw how !t was, apologized, ob tained definite directions as to the locality of Mr. Moses Blakes heuse, and departed. The less I say of my visit there the better. Bessie weighed a couple of hundred, to say the least, and was red and healthy as a washerwoman. A fine girl, no doubt, but not to my taste. I recuperated speedily, went home and married Araminta Jones.  Good Literature.

document.text: Yes, I ship a good many, said Evans. Why do you ask? T v e just had all my white Leg horns stolenforty of them. Every one round here is losing chickens. Now those chickens have to be mar keted somewhereand not around here. Its fifty miles to the city, which is the safest place to m arket them. If I stole chickens, Id freight them down, dressed and packed in barrels. So I thought if anybody round here was doing the thieving and the thieves, whoever they are, take the local paper, and certainly do know this part of the county as well as their hand  I m ight get some hint from your shipments. Thats a first rate idea, said the young man. But I dont remember any special shipper of dressed poul try in barrels. The W alter boys pack that way, but I guess were not sus pecting them! Mrs. Dixon sends a barrel now and then. So do the peo ple on the Lawrence farm th ats been an experimental poultry farm for the last year. I hear they report they lost badly through a raid by the thieves two months ago. The Elliotts, over at Orwell, send dressed poultry, too, but never very much. It doesnt seem------- .No, it doesnt, said Dorothy, looking perplexed. But these chick ens have got to get to market, Frank, somehow. Ive started to hunt this county over till I find whats become of them. I guess Id better drive to the other stations up and down the road. Theyd be likely to choose a stupid agent to ship through, so I dnt wonder they keep away from here. Then she flushed a t having paid Frank a compliment, and Frank flushed, too, with pleasure, for he knew that his pretty schoolmate never said things unless she meant them. It p u t him on his mettle. But see here, Dorothy, why do you have to drive up and down the road? W hats the m atter with my telegraphing instead? Come in and sit down, and I ll get you all the in formation you want in half an hour. So Dorothy sat and listened to the clicking w.ires, and took some brief notes on a telegraph pad that Frank pushed over to her across the table. Wagner, at Dorrance station, says that the Lawrence farm sends a bar rel now and then and a crate occa sionally. The Widow Ransom is the heaviest shipper sends both crates and barrels. Jones, at Pond station, says Hank Janeway ships a barrel sometimes so does the Lawrence farm. The Browns send a crate now and then white Leghorns and Ply mouth Rocks. Collins, at Pelham Junction, says that Mrs. Robinson ships more than anybody else, but Jim Henry sends a barrel or a crate now and then, and so does the Law rence peoplePlymouth Rocks, most ly. King, at Bellevue station, says everybody sends in crates, except a barrel now and then from the Law rence people and Sally W alker. Frank leaned back and whistled softly. Dorothy smiled and pushed the telegraph pad under his eyes. Five underlinings marked the name Lawrence repeated in each of the five reports from Milby, Dorrance, Pond, Pelham and Bellevue. You clever girl! said Frank. Youve got hold of the right end. No honest poultry farm ever shipped that much to the city, and through five different stations in small lots. But supposing its so, how are we go ing to prove it? The man doesnt live who can identify an ordinary white Leghorn hen or Plymouth Rock pul let. But the girl does! cried Dorothy, triumphantly. Since day before yesterday I can pick out any one of my forty Leghorns with absolute cer tainty, Frank. I I dipped their legs, every one of them, in a fast black that wont come off, so that I could know them again if they were stolen. Frank Evans lay back in his chair and laughed delightedly. Dorothy, you always were at the head of the class, he said, heartily. But what are you going to do now? Im going to the Lawrence farm , said Dorothy, unfastening the hitch ing strap. You mustnt do that. They might do you an injury. W ait till I can get a constable and a search warrant. You m ustnt go alone, Dorothy. , I wont have it. I dont mind a search w arrant, said Dorothy, with composure. That is what I brought this for. She pulled out the mysterious box, and disclosed various brightly labeled bottles and packages. I am Miss Jane Smith, Frank, agent for these poultry remedies, which I am driv ing about the county introducing among intelligent poultry farmers. I shall get into the Lawrence chicken yards, and come away again without any trouble, thank you. But I should like the constable to be at the end of the lane, ready to come in a little later. Ill get Dick Williams to tend the station, said Frank, and drive over with you p u t the constables and

document.text: Wronged woman in Court. James H. Dickinson, a handsome young fellow, was convicted of adul tery upon five niinutesLdeliberation of a jury in Judge Coxs court this morning. He was stylishly dressed this morning, andat first seemed self- possessed  but his cheeks burned aud tears came into his eyes as the testi mony opened the penitentiary door for him. His wife, who was Maggie L- Jones, sat in court, while Mary Ricker, the girl he had wronged,and her father, Robt. Ricker, of No. 30 G. street northeast, testified against him. When the jury returned a verdict his connsel, Messrs. E. B. Hay and James B. Green, moved for a new trial and asked his release on bond. Mr. Jeffords, for the government, asked that the bond be raised from 300 to 5.000. Judge Cox said  2 ,- 500. Dickinson was committed till he can furnish the amount..Wash ington Times.

document.text: written by Miss Jones of Church. The convention then adjourned for a recess of an hour. A bountiful dinner was served aud full justice was done to spring chicken. The afternoon service was not so well atteuded, and the shady grove proved very attractive to the young people, and Mr. Coach suggested they were planning work for Dr. Taylor go oonsuinate while the Dr. smiled pleasantly. Mr. Warren made a ielpful sug gestion to superintendents and was followed by a pleasing address to teachers by Mr. Couch. Dr. Taylor and Bro. Shearer also took part in the discussion. On Sunday morning Mr. Couch read an essay on How to have a good Sunday school. The subject was comprehensive and showed ex perience on the part of the writer, Miss Lacy Caldwell. A sermon was delivered by Bro. Warren after which the convention adjourned until 8 p. m. X.

document.text: Work was commenced on the big business and tenement block whioh Hr. D. 8. Jones some time ago arranged to build at the cor ner Of Twenty-eighth street and Lafayette avenue, Newport News. The block wUl be four stories high and have room enough on the first floor to acoomihodate several large stores. It is to be of briek. S, T. Bray, aged tblrty-slx yean, was found dead In bis bouse In Danville. The body was suspended by a rope from the top of a door frame, and from its condition the act must have been committed early tn the week. No one bos been staying in the house with Mr. Bray recently. On July 20 last Bray carried his wife and child to her fathers, at Christie, Va., and returned to Danville In a despondent mood. On August 27 he sold his interest in the Carter Maoblne Company to his partner, and stnee then had made several efforts to buy an Interest in established bouses here but without suocess. For several months past Bray had aoted strangely, and there is not much doubt but that constant brooding on some trouble, which he did not disclose, had affected his mind. Walter Witt, a brakeman on the Virginia Midland Division of the Southern Railway, was instantly killed at Staunton river bridge. Witt was passing over the cars on a freight train and his bead was struck by one of the beams of the bridge structure. The body was taken to Danville where Witt resided. The young brakeman had been marrlod only two weeks. Senator Faulkner Is reoeivlng the congrat ulations of his friends over the arrival of hie flrst grandchild, a son to Mr. and Mrs. Carter, In Wyoming. Mrs. Ruth Witt, of Handley, died Friday, Aged about ninety years. Mr. Oabriel Johnson died, after a protrac ted illness, at his home, near Cliff Mills, Fauquier county, in the eightieth year of his age. The ease of W. W. George against the Mathleson Alkali Works of Saltollle, Va., for alleged damages in the sum of 20,000, was decided In the Circuit Cqurt of Smythe County against the plaintiff. Mr. Oeorge was seriously injured in an accident at the alkali works a year ago. He also has a suit pending against the Norfolk aad Western Railway for alleged damages. The farmers of Caroline are still shipping portions of their last years crop of tobacco and are obtaining good prtceB. This county Is especially adapted to the raising of fine grades of tobacco, whioh command the high est prices. Judge H. M. Ford has returned to Lynch burg from Richmond and Norfolk, where he secured a pardon for W. E. Turner, former ly of the Norfolk and Western Railroad, who has been in the penitentiary for three years. It seems that Turner was the victim of a conspiracy of his wife, who accused him of an assault on her daughter, for which he was sentenced In the Corporation Court of Norfolk to ten years in the penitentiary. After the trial his wife secured a divorce and married an Englishman. Affidavits were made showing that her people admitted that It was a job put up on Turner by his wife, and it was on the strength of these that he was pardoned. The barn and contents, embracing farm ing Implements and about 600 bushels of wheat, on what is known as the Cassidy farm, near Waterford, now owned by Mrs. H. O. Gross, was ttoally destroyed by fire. Mr. Roger Jones farms the place and had housed his wheat crop in the barn, which was a very large one. He was thrashing his wheat, the thrasher being in the barn and the engine just outside. A spark Ignaled the straw and everything went up In flames. The thrasher belongod to George Fry. On the 16th Instant the Hon. William Lynne Wilson will be formally Installed as President of Washington and Lee Univer sity. The exercises pill take place in the university chapel, beginning at 11 oclock. Addresses will be delivered by President Patton, of Princeton University, President Oilman, of Johoa Hopkins University, and Chanoellor Kirkland, of Vanderbilt Univer sity. Following this there will be an address of ao icptance by President Wilson. Then the oath of office will be administered to him by the university rector, Judge William Mo- Laugblin. At 2 oclock In the afternoon a banquet will be held in the university gym nasium. Many distinguished educators of the North and South will be present. Mrs. Ella M. Burkholder, wife of Dr. N. M. Burkholder, died suddenly of heart fail ure on August 29 at their residence Fort Lynne, near Harrisonburg. Mrs. Burk holder was a daughter of Dr. Beuben Moore and a granddaughter of the late Samuel Cootes, of Rockingham. Mr. Chas. B. Wood, the pioneer fruit grower of Rappahannock county, was offer ed last week by John J. Miller, 5,000 for his apple crop, which offer he refused. The trees In h!s orchard, which is the finest in that section, are loaded down with the finest fruit, being unusally large and per fect.

document.text: Womens Missionary Society of liberty Baptist Church The Women Missionary Society of Liberty Baptist Church, or rather known first as the Ladie  Aid Society, was organized by Rev. Dr Henry W. Tribble in the year of his pastorate of this church, in 18 85. It was a small and feeble beginning but an earnest Christian spirit and effort tup ported the movement of this struggling band of Christian workers. Dr. Tribble even in vited the men to join the society so as to encourage and help the ladies in their Christian work Miss Sue Sears was elected president for several years, and she was active and efficient in the society, as in all other church work, wherever her consecrated life found work for the Heavenly Father Miss Sears best endeavors for His cause were always given I remember a few of the orig inal members Mrs. William H Gills, Mrs. William H. Abbitt Mrs. Joel Oawthorn, Mrs. T. A Caldwell, Mrs. C. W. Hancock Misses Sis OConner, Sis Ab bitt, and Lula Jones. This society met in the Amen corn er of the chnrch for years, after the regular monthly service on the 3rd Sunday of each month This society did much church work in individual ways, but rarely ever had any money, ex cept a few cents in the treasury. We tried lawn parties, lectures, oyster suppers, tableaux, etc. But rains, illness, or something seemed to break us up, minus of finances. If we raised fire or ten dollars a year for our society we thought we had done well, aa in those days ladies Ad minis- were not supposed to have any

document.text: With the lovely spring day to our advantage, a large group of .friend and members were out to attend the regular preaching ser vice at the St. Luke Church Sunday, April 20 at the 11 p.m. service. Everyone was so happy to have Rev.. J. E. McLaughlin back at church. After going through, an illness of some weeks, he was fo charge and Rev. Alvin Jones assisted him with the devotion. The Junior and Senior Choirs, combined gave the nrbric. Mrs. Josephine Nowlin was at the piano. Rev. McLaughlin had the regular conference with the little children. He then gave the message for the day. Text was found in Jude 24-25.Now unto him who is able to keep you from stumbling and falling for glory and honor act. The subject was Disturbing Signs of Decaying Spirits. This was well taken. The offering was good. The ones who had been ill and under surgery were present at the services. Namely Mrs. Sally Evans, Mrs. Catherine Tweedy, Mrs. Evans testified how great God -was to her . St. Luke Choir and pastor are invited to Mt. Pleasant for Sunday, April 27 at 6 p.m. for the pastors anniversary. Mr. and Mrs. David Gains are moving into their new home on Rt. 1, Concord. e hope for them much happiness and success.

document.text: With the lovely day for Easter a large group of  members, friends, and out of towners attended the regu lar preaching services at the St. Luke Baptist Church Sunday at 1100 a.m. A nice lot attended Sunday School also. Rev. J.E. Mclaughlin was present, but still improving from the illness for some weeks. He did not preach. Rev. Alvin Jones was also, on the Rostrum, but Rev. Singletary was in charge. Tne Sr. choir gave music for the Easter occasion after remarks of greetings Rev. Singletary began to speak text 1st Cor.16 44-49 . The new spiritual body after a prayer asking guidance from above he began to speak it was a great message dealing with death and the resurrec tion. Well taken. Then communion was,, served. The offering for the  day was good. On the 5th Sunday, the Cornerstone Sunday School union met with the White Oak Grove Church School Rev. H.J. Hendrick is Pastor, Deacon J.D. Moore Vice President was in charge. Sunday school was enjoyed as taught by teachers of respective clas ses. The Vice President conducted an  uplifiting review. All seemed to take inAhe high points as brought out. Ail schools were represented there. As usual the youth program was a high feature to the occasion and enjoyed by ail. Rev. Hendricks was the speaker for the day. Text Hebrew 4-12th The-Bible the book that calls this was a great message, food for thought. On Saturday, April 5th many of the St. Luke members and many other friends attended the lovelv wedding of Miss Shirley Marshall, the daughter of . Deacon and Mrs. Samuel Marshall to Mr. Howard Harrington of Baltimore Md. The reception was held at the home  th e bride. Ail was lovely. The cake was beautiful a 3 tier kind.
